answer_html: \(\int_1^4{}x\cos\left(\frac{\pi}{x}\right)=2.265092039\) which already to this low approximation shows fairly good accuracy.
answer_latex: $\int_1^4{}x\cos\left(\frac{\pi}{x}\right)=2.265092039$ which already to this low approximation shows fairly good accuracy.
hints_html:
The Trapezoid Rule in full generality is

\(T_{n} = \frac{\Delta x}{2} \Big(f(x_{0}) + 2f(x_{1}) + 2f(x_{2}) + ... + 2f(x_{n-1}) + f(x_{n}) \Big)\)
hints_latex:
The Trapezoid Rule in full generality is

$T_{n} = \frac{\Delta x}{2} \Big(f(x_{0}) + 2f(x_{1}) + 2f(x_{2}) + ... + 2f(x_{n-1}) + f(x_{n}) \Big)$
hints_raw:
The Trapezoid Rule in full generality is

<math>
T_{n} = \frac{\Delta x}{2} \Big(f(x_{0}) + 2f(x_{1}) + 2f(x_{2}) + ... + 2f(x_{n-1}) + f(x_{n}) \Big)
</math>
question: 1 (d)
sols_html:
Recall that when \(\displaystyle n=3\), \(\displaystyle a=1\), and \(\displaystyle b=4\) we have

\(\displaystyle \Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n} = \frac{4-1}{3} = 1\)

and that

\(\displaystyle x_{i} = a + i\Delta x = 1 + i(1) = 1 + i.\)

We plug in these values to see that

\[\begin{aligned} T_{3} &= \frac{\Delta x}{2} \Big(f(x_{0}) + 2f(x_{1}) + 2f(x_{2}) + f(x_{3}) \Big)\\ &= \frac{1}{2} \Big(f(1+0) + 2f(1 + 1) + 2f(1 + 2) + f(1 + 3) \Big) \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \Big((1\cos(\pi/(1))) + 2(2\cos(\pi/2)) + 2(3\cos(\pi/3)) + (4\cos(\pi/4)) \Big) \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \Big(\cos(\pi) + 4\cos(\pi/2) + 6\cos(\pi/3) + 4\cos(\pi/4) \Big) \end{aligned}\]

completing the question. Note that if we actually compute the value we get that, \(T_3=2.414213562\) and that,

\[\begin{aligned} \int_1^4{}x\cos\left(\frac{\pi}{x}\right)=2.265092039\end{aligned}\]

which already to this low approximation shows fairly good accuracy.
sols_latex:
Recall that when $\displaystyle n=3$, $\displaystyle a=1$, and
$\displaystyle b=4$ we have

$\displaystyle \Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n} = \frac{4-1}{3} = 1$

and that

$\displaystyle x_{i} = a + i\Delta x = 1 + i(1) = 1 + i.$

We plug in these values to see that

\begin{align*}
T_{3} &= \frac{\Delta x}{2} \Big(f(x_{0}) + 2f(x_{1}) + 2f(x_{2}) + f(x_{3}) \Big)\\
&= \frac{1}{2} \Big(f(1+0) + 2f(1 + 1) + 2f(1 + 2) + f(1 + 3) \Big) \\
&= \frac{1}{2} \Big((1\cos(\pi/(1))) + 2(2\cos(\pi/2)) + 2(3\cos(\pi/3)) + (4\cos(\pi/4)) \Big) \\
&= \frac{1}{2} \Big(\cos(\pi) + 4\cos(\pi/2) + 6\cos(\pi/3) + 4\cos(\pi/4) \Big) 
\end{align*}

completing the question. Note that if we actually compute the value we
get that, $T_3=2.414213562$ and that,

\begin{align*}
\int_1^4{}x\cos\left(\frac{\pi}{x}\right)=2.265092039
\end{align*}

which already to this low approximation shows fairly good accuracy.
sols_raw:
Recall that when <math>\displaystyle n=3</math>, <math>\displaystyle a=1</math>, and <math>\displaystyle b=4</math> we have

<math>
\displaystyle \Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n} = \frac{4-1}{3} = 1
</math>

and that

<math>
\displaystyle x_{i} = a + i\Delta x = 1 + i(1) = 1 + i.
</math>

We plug in these values to see that

<math>
\begin{align}
T_{3} &= \frac{\Delta x}{2} \Big(f(x_{0}) + 2f(x_{1}) + 2f(x_{2}) + f(x_{3}) \Big)\\
&= \frac{1}{2} \Big(f(1+0) + 2f(1 + 1) + 2f(1 + 2) + f(1 + 3) \Big) \\
&= \frac{1}{2} \Big((1\cos(\pi/(1))) + 2(2\cos(\pi/2)) + 2(3\cos(\pi/3)) + (4\cos(\pi/4)) \Big) \\
&= \frac{1}{2} \Big(\cos(\pi) + 4\cos(\pi/2) + 6\cos(\pi/3) + 4\cos(\pi/4) \Big) 
\end{align}
</math>

completing the question.  Note that if we actually compute the value we get that, <math>T_3=2.414213562</math> and that,

:<math>
\int_1^4{}x\cos\left(\frac{\pi}{x}\right)=2.265092039
</math>

which already to this low approximation shows fairly good accuracy.
statement_html:
Write down the Trapezoidal Rule approximation \(\displaystyle T_{3}\) for

\(\int_{1}^{4}x\cos(\pi/x)\, dx\).

Leave your answer expressed as a sum involving cosines.
statement_latex:
Write down the Trapezoidal Rule approximation $\displaystyle T_{3}$ for

$\int_{1}^{4}x\cos(\pi/x)\, dx$.

Leave your answer expressed as a sum involving cosines.
statement_raw:
Write down the Trapezoidal Rule approximation <math> \displaystyle T_{3} </math> for 

<math> \int_{1}^{4}x\cos(\pi/x)\, dx </math>. 

Leave your answer expressed as a sum involving cosines.
